Math Commands

Math: Change Variable

Create or change a variable. If you try to execute math (such as +=) on a variable that has not been created yet, it will be set to 0.

Variables are containers for storing data values (including numbers and strings), that can be reused over and over again. Variable names are case sensitive, meaning that "Variable" and "variable" are not going to have the same value. Variable names can contain numbers, letters and _, but cannot start with a number itself. For example, 2cool will not work as a variable name.

Value of a variable can be:

  • Another variable
  • Real value (number)
  • String - needs to be wrapped in " ".
  • Stack value - [position]stackname
  • Math expression including variables and Complex Math operators. Must be wrapped in ().

All variables inside Receiver are global and get deleted every time you close or reset Receiver. They are not unique to a button that created them and any button/deck can access them.
You can press Tab in the main screen of the Receiver to view all the existing variables, strings will be wrapped in " ".
Variables can be used as parameters or inside any string. If the input box name contains *, you can just type the variable name as it is. If the input box does not contain *, you need to wrap any variable like this: /$variable$/. Wrapping variables tells LioranBoard to work with the value of the variable rather than the variable itself.


You cannot mix strings and real values in math expressions. It will make the Receiver crash.


Name Type Description
Variable String Name of the variable
Operator Dropdown menu Operator you wish to use on the value.
Var./Real/"String" * Variable, real or string Whatever you want to set the variable value to.

Math: Variable Transition

Transition a variable from a starting value to a final value over a given duration.
This command can act as a timer to trigger other commands or buttons.
For example, if you set the start value to 10, final value to 0 and duration to 10000ms (=10 seconds), it will decrease the value by 1 every second and reach 0 after exactly 10 seconds.

Name Type Description
Variable String Name of the variable. Accepts anything including spaces and numbers.
Start Value * Real (number) Starting point (where the counting starts from)
Final Value * Real (number) Finishing point (where the counting stops at)
Allow Float boolean Float=values with decimal points, int=values without decimal points (rounded down)
Dur.(MS) Int Duration of the transition

Math: Clamp

Clamps a variable (number) between two values.

  1. If value of the variable < minimum allowed value, returns minimum allowed value.
  2. If value of the variable > maximum allowed value, returns maximum allowed value.
  3. If value of the variable is within the allowed range, returns the original value.

Do not use Math:Clamp on strings and String:Clamp on real values, as this will result in an error and LB crashing.

Name Type Description
Variable String Name of a variable to clamp
Min * Real (number) Minimum value allowed
Max * Real (number) Maximum value allowed

Math: Random

Returns a variable with a random value (number) between minimum and maximum possible value.
This is a basic command you can use for showing random images, playing random videos/sounds, picking a random viewer from chat etc.
If you wish to have more power over randomizing values (like adding weights), it is best to use Stacks instead.

For example, if you have 10 different images in a folder with the same name formatting (image1.png, image2.png, image3.png) and you wish to pick a random image and trigger it in OBS, you can use Math:Random and Source Change Settings command.

Name Type Description
Variable String Name of a variable to save the random value
Min * Real (number) Minimum value possible
Max * Real (number) Maximum value possible
Float boolean If Float (number with decimal points) is set to True, it will return a random value between maximum and minimum possible value, but never the maximum or minimum value itself.
If Float is set to False, it will return a random value, including the maximum and minimum possible value.
Any float value in minimum or maximum value will be omitted if set to False.

Math: Clear Variable

Deletes a variable. It will also remove it from the list of variables (when you press Tab in the main Receiver menu).
Useful command to keep your list clean and uncluttered.

Name Type Description
Variable String Name of a variable to delete

Math: String to Real

Turns a string into a real value (=number).

  • Turning a string "-1.20" into a real value returns -1.20.
  • Turning a string "Hello World" into a real value returns 0.
  • Turning a string "123 Hello World" into a real value returns 123.
  • Turning a string "Hello World 123" into a real value returns 0.
  • Turning a string "123 Hello World 456" into a real value returns 123.
Name Type Description
Variable String Name of a variable to save the string as a real value
String Variable String Name of a variable containing the string you wish to become real

Math: Hex to Real

Converts a hexadecimal string into a real (decimal) number.

Name Type Description
Variable String Name of a variable to save the hex as a real value
String Variable String Name of a variable containing the hex you wish to become real

Math: Pull Source Value

Pulls the last known value of a source. Will return 0 if the source doesn't exist.
This may not be accurate if the source is inside a group. In this case try putting the group name instead of the scene name or using a nested scene instead of a group.

Very useful command to use together with Source:Motion commands. For example, you can pull the current X and Y position of a source and then use Source Motion: Position to smoothly move it across the screen.

Name Type Description
Scene String Scene name containing the source
Source String Source name to pull the value
Variable String Variable name to save the pulled value into
Pull Dropdown menu
  • X/Y position - returns position of the source
  • X/Y scale - returns scale of the source, 1=100%
  • Rotation - returns the degree of rotation of the source (0-360)
  • Volume - returns the volume percentage of the source (0-100)
  • Muted - returns 1 or 0 whether the source is muted or not
  • Visible - returns 1 or 0 whether the source is visible or not

Math: Pull Filter Visibility

Pulls the last known visibility of a specified filter

Name Type Description
Source String Source name containing the filter
Filter String Name of a filter to pull visibility from
Variable String Variable name to save the pulled value into

Math: Trigger Pull

This command is used in combination with any triggers you set up for the button.
For example, if you set up a button with a Twitch Subs trigger, you can then pull the subscriber's name once it gets activated.

Important: Math:Trigger Pull command must be in the same button as your trigger.

Name Type Description
Variable String Variable name to save the pulled value into
Pull Value Dropdown List Value you wish to pull from the trigger
Turn to real boolean Whether you want to turn the pulled value to real (number)

Pull Types (numeric value required for 1.42 version and older):

Chat message trigger
Value Description
0 Display name of the viewer who sent the message
1 The whole message
2 Viewer's username
3 Emotes list.
Basic format: FirstEmoteID:FirstIndex-LastIndex/SecondEmoteID:FirstIndex-LastIndex
Message containing multiple emotes will be formatted such as: FirstEmoteID:FirstIndex(1)-LastIndex(1),FirstIndex(2)-LastIndex(2),FirstIndex(3)-LastIndex(3)

Get emotes image by ID at this URL https://static-cdn.jtvnw.net/emoticons/v1/EMOTEID/1.0You can change the last part to 1.0, 2.0 or 3.0 to get different sizes. Example.
4 Badges.
Basic format: FirstBadgeName/version,SecondBadgeName/version
For example: broadcaster/1, subscriber/0
Global Badges List: https://badges.twitch.tv/v1/badges/global/display
Channel Badges List:https://badges.twitch.tv/v1/badges/channels/CHANNEL_ID/display
To find the badge ID in the JSON, look for BadgeList.badge_sets[BADGENAME].versions[VERSION].image_url_1x. The last part 1x can be changed to 2x, 3x or 4x for bigger size. Example.
5 Channel Name where the message originated from. Will return w if it's a whisper.
6 Chat name color in hexadecimal format.
Bits trigger
Value Description
0 Name of the viewer who donated the bits (display name not available)
1 Amount of bits donated
2 Amount TOTAL of bits donated ever by the viewer
3 Message from the viewer
Subscriber Trigger
Value Description
0 Viewer username who subbed or gifted the sub.
1 Tier of the sub. Returns "Tier 1", "Tier 2", "Tier 3", or "Prime".
2 Type of the sub. Returns "sub", "resub", "subgift", or "anonsubgift".
3 Recipient (if the sub was gifted)
4 Message from the subscriber
5 Total number of months subbed (will return 0 if not found)
6 Display name of the subscriber
7 Display name of the recipient
8 Community sub check. Can be 0 or 1. (version 1.43 and newer)
Gift Sub Amount
Value Description
0 Name of the gifter ("anonymousgifter" if anon gift subs)
1 Display Name of the gifter ("AnAnonymousGifter" if anon gift subs)
2 Amount of subs gifted
3 Tier Type: "Tier 1","Tier 2" or "Tier 3"
Raid and Host trigger
Value Description
0 Name of the hoster/raider (display name delivered only during a host)
1 Amount of viewers
2 Display name of the hoster/raider
Channel point redeem trigger
Value Description
0 Name of the viewer who redeemed it (display name not available)
1 Name of the redeem
2 Viewer Message (if entering a message is required)
3 Reward ID of the specified channel point
4 Redeem ID of the redemption itself (used for cancelling/fulfilling it via Channel Points extension)
Channel point redeem trigger with message
Value Description
0 Name of the viewer who redeemed it (display name not available)
1 Name of the redeem
2 Full viewer Message
3 Reward ID of the specified channel point
4 Redeem ID of the redemption itself (used for cancelling/fulfilling it via Channel Points extension)
Extension Trigger
Value Description
0 Extension trigger name
1 Value1
2 Value2
3 etc. Value3 etc.
